Description of the research.1: This simulator accompanies the report of the [EU Tax Observatory](https://taxobservatory.eu/), *Collecting the tax deficit of multinational companies: Simulations for the European Union* (June 2021), as well as the complementary notes released in July and October 2021.
Description of the research.2: This study estimates how much tax revenue the European Union could collect by imposing a minimum tax on the profits of multinational companies. It relies on the notion of tax deficit, defined as the difference between what multinationals currently pay in taxes, and what they would pay if they were subject to a minimum tax rate in each country. Three ways for EU countries to collect this tax deficit are considered:
Description of the research.3: * an international agreement on a minimum tax of the type currently discussed within the OECD / G20 Inclusive Framework on BEPS, in which scenario a minimum tax rate of 15% could increase tax revenues in the European Union by about €80 billion in 2021;
Description of the research.4: * an incomplete international agreement in which only EU countries apply a minimum tax. Substantial corporate income tax revenue gains would then come from collecting a portion of the tax deficit of non-EU multinationals;
Description of the research.5: * a “first-mover” scenario, in which one country alone decides to collect the tax deficit of multinational companies. In June 2021, we estimated that on average, a first mover in the European Union would increase its corporate tax revenues by close to 70% relative to its current corporate tax collection.
Description of the research.6: This simulator was designed for policy makers, journalists, members of civil society, and all citizens in each EU country to assess the revenue potential from minimum taxation on both domestic and foreign firms. Each of the aforementioned scenarios can be investigated on a specific page, accessible via the left-hand sidebar, that allows to simulate corporate tax revenue gains from any minimum effective tax rate between 10% and 50%.

Case study with one multinational.1: This page aims at illustrating the notion of tax deficit with a few examples of multinationals that release the relevant data publicly. Indeed, since 2015, banks with a consolidated turnover above 750 million euros and that operate in the European Union are required to publicly disclose the activity of all their affiliates regarding the allocation of their income, profit and taxes. Besides, several non-bank multinationals have voluntarily started disclosing their country-by-country report, which tabulates how much revenues, profits and taxes they have registered in each country of residence of their subsidiaries.
Case study with one multinational.2: In this section, you can use the dropdown to select a European multinational company and examine the additional corporate tax revenue that the headquarter country could collect by imposing a minimum tax rate on all its activities.
Case study with one multinational.3: The bar chart below shows how this additional corporate tax revenue varies depending on the minimum rate chosen. As in our initial report (June 2021), we consider 4 reference rates of respectively 15%, 21%, 25% and 30%.

Multilateral agreement simulation.1: This page is dedicated to the simulation of a multilateral agreement on minimum taxation. We consider an international agreement on a minimum tax, of the same type as in the Pillar Two of the [October 8th joint statement](https://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/statement-on-a-two-pillar-solution-to-address-the-tax-challenges-arising-from-the-digitalisation-of-the-economy-october-2021.pdf) of the members of the OECD / G20 Inclusive Framework. In this scenario, each headquarter country collects the tax deficit of its own multinationals.
Multilateral agreement simulation.2: For instance, with the internationally agreed minimum tax rate of 15%, if a German company has an effective tax rate of 10% on the profits it records in Singapore, then Germany would impose an additional tax of 5% on these profits to arrive at an effective rate of 15%. More generally, Germany would collect extra taxes so that its multinationals pay at least 15% in taxes on the profits they book in each country and other nations would proceed similarly.
Multilateral agreement simulation.3: In this section, you can simulate the results of such a multilateral agreement and choose the agreed-upon minimum effective tax rate. As an indication, the latest agreement has validated a minimum tax rate of 15%, while France and Germany had previously advocated for a 21% minimum effective tax rate. The benchmark minimum tax rate considered in our initial report (June 2021) was 25%, a relatively modest rate in an international and historical perspective.
Multilateral agreement simulation.4: Importantly, these computations correspond to a minimum tax without so-called substance-based carve-outs: you will find more information on these exemptions and be able to simulate their effect on the dedicated page, accessible via the left-hand side dropdown. Plus, note that the methodology producing the above results and the potential data issues involved are discussed in our report of June 2021 and in subsequent notes.

Partial cooperation scenario.1: This page is dedicated to an imperfect cooperation scenario, in which only EU countries apply a minimum tax, while non-EU countries do not change their tax policies. In this scenario, each EU country would collect the tax deficit of its own multinationals (as in the full coordination scenario), plus a portion of the tax deficit of multinationals incorporated outside of the European Union. This portion would be based on the geography of sales to final customers.
Partial cooperation scenario.2: For instance, if a company incorporated in the United Kingdom makes 20% of its final (i.e., non-intragroup) sales in Germany, then Germany would collect 20% of the tax deficit of this company, if it has any.
Partial cooperation scenario.3: In this section, you can simulate the results of such a partial cooperation and choose the minimum effective tax rate applied by EU member states. The table then indicates the corporate income tax revenue gains of each in-sample EU country under this agreement.

Unilateral implementation scenario.1: This page is dedicated to the unilateral implementation or “first-mover” scenario, in which one country alone decides to collect the tax deficit of multinational companies. This first-mover would collect the full tax deficit of its own multinationals, plus a portion (proportional to the destination of sales) of the tax deficit of all foreign multinationals.
Unilateral implementation scenario.2: For instance, if this first-mover is Germany, then Germany would collect 100% of the tax deficit of German multinationals, plus a portion of the tax deficit (if there is one) of French, UK, US, etc. multinationals. This portion would be equal to the fraction of the global sales these multinationals make in Germany.
Unilateral implementation scenario.3: In this section, you can select which country would be this first-mover and observe how the minimum rate it will impose influences its corporate tax revenue gains. The table indicates the country of residence of the multinationals whose tax deficit it would collect, entirely (for its own multinationals) or partly (for the foreign ones, based on the location of their sales).

Substance-based carve-outs.1: In October 2021, 136 countries agreed to a minimum tax rate of 15% on their multinationals’ profits. The [joint statement](https://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/statement-on-a-two-pillar-solution-to-address-the-tax-challenges-arising-from-the-digitalisation-of-the-economy-october-2021.pdf) then released includes an exemption that could reduce revenues from this global minimum tax, the so-called **substance-based carve-outs**. These allow multinationals, in each country where they operate, to reduce the profits subject to the minimum tax by a share of the value of their tangible assets and payroll.
Substance-based carve-outs.2: This mechanism has deep consequences on the objective of the policy and significantly decreases potential revenue gains. In a dedicated [note](https://www.taxobservatory.eu/minimizing-the-minimum-tax-the-critical-effect-of-substance-carve-outs/) and in the [update](https://www.taxobservatory.eu/revenue-effects-of-the-global-minimum-tax-country-by-country-estimates/) of our benchmark estimates, we model how this carve-out would affect revenues from a global minimum tax and find that these could be reduced by 14% to 23% in the European Union relative to a 15% minimum tax without carve-out.
